metadata.title: Hindu Scriptures Classification
metadata.description: Detailed classification of Sanatana Dharma texts based on Shruti and Smriti, as described in Hindu-scriptures.txt

nodes.name:
Sanatana Dharma
Scriptures
nodes.description: Complete classification of Hindu religious texts (Shruti and Smriti)

details.overview: Hindu scriptures are divided into Shruti (heard/revealed) and Smriti (remembered/composed) texts.
details.significance: These texts form the foundation of Hindu philosophy, theology, and practice.

nodes.name:
Shruti
(श्रुति)
nodes.description: That which has been heard or revealed; considered eternal and divine.

details.origin: Rishis heard Vedas in deep meditation (samadhi).
details.forms: Comes in two forms: Nigamas (Vedas) and Agamas.

nodes.name:
Vedas
(वेद)
nodes.description: It is said/believed that Rishi in the state of Tapasya heard Vedas directly from Parabrahma/Parameshwara. Vedas are called अपौरुषेय that means it is not created by man i.e impersonal/authorless and believed to be the words of Ishwara, eternal. Rishish are द्रष्टा (seers) rather than author of Veda.

details.parts: Each Veda has four parts: Samhita (core hymns), Brahmana (rituals/commentaries), Aranyaka (forest treatises), Upanishad (philosophy).

nodes.name: Samhita
nodes.description: Samhita is the core part of Veda (which is heard by Rishis)

nodes.name: Brahmana
nodes.description: Brahmanas are the interpretation and commentaries on Mantra/Samhita part of Vedas which helps to explain, understand the meaning and significance of Veda and also provides the way of doing rites (i.e rituals). As it gives Karma Kanda in Vedic Yajna, known as Karma Kanda (कर्मकाण्ड) part of Veda. Due to very much significance/influence of Brahmanas (ब्राह्मणग्रन्थ), it is considered as the part of Veda and hence classified as Shruti. Sayanacharya in his Bhashya on Rigveda, said that मंत्र ब्राह्मणात्मको वेद which means Mantra(मंत्र) and Brahmanatmak(ब्राह्मणात्मक) combined forms Veda. मन्त्रब्राह्मणयोर्वेदनामधेयम् (From Aapstamb Srauta Sutra) means Mantra as well as Brahmana parts are Veda.

nodes.name:
Atharvaveda
(अथर्ववेद)
nodes.description: Veda of everyday life and practical knowledge.

nodes.name:
Agamas
(आगम)
nodes.description: Manuals of Divine Worship; parallel to Vedas.

details.forms: Three main types: Vaishnava, Shaiva, Shakta.
details.note: Agamas focus on devotional worship, rituals, and temple construction.

details.classes: Pancharatra (7 groups: Brahma, Shaiva, Kaumara, Vasishtha, Kapila, Gautamiya, Naradiya), Vaikhanasa, Pratishthasara, Vijñana-lalita.

details.important: Mahanirvana Tantra, Kularnava Tantra, Kulasara Tantra, Prapanchasara Tantra, Tantraraja Rudra-Yamala, Brahma-Yamala, Vishnu-Yamala, Todala Tantra.

nodes.name:
Smriti
(स्मृति)
nodes.description: That which is remembered or based on memory; human compositions.

details.nature: Texts composed by Rishis, based on Shruti.
details.authority: Secondary to Shruti but highly revered.
details.examples: Vedanga, Upaveda, Upanga, Dharma Shastra, Purana, Itihasa, Darshana, etc.

nodes.name:
Vedanga
(वेदाङ्ग)
nodes.description: Six limbs of the Vedas; auxiliary sciences.

details.purpose: Essential for studying and understanding Vedas.
details.count: Six: Shiksha, Vyakarana, Nirukta, Chhanda, Jyotisha, Kalpa.

nodes.name:
Nirukta
(निरुक्त)
nodes.description: Etymology and explanation of difficult words.

details.propagators: Many Acharyas; includes Srautasutras, Grihyasutras, Shulbasutras, Dharmasutras.

nodes.name:
Upaveda
(उपवेद)
nodes.description: The Upavedas are auxiliary disciplines traditionally associated with each of the four Vedas. They cover applied knowledge such as medicine, warfare, music, and architecture.

nodes.name:
Āyurveda
(आयुर्वेद)
nodes.description: The science of life, health, and medicine. Associated with the Ṛgveda. Major texts include Charaka Saṁhitā and Suśruta Saṁhitā.

nodes.name:
Dhanurveda
(धनुर्वेद)
nodes.description: The science of warfare, archery, and military arts. Associated with the Yajurveda. Covers martial disciplines, weapons, and battle strategies.

nodes.name:
Gāndharvaveda
(गान्धर्ववेद)
nodes.description: The science of music, sound, and performing arts. Associated with the Sāmaveda. It forms the foundation for Indian classical music and dance.

nodes.name:
Sthāpatya Veda
(स्थापत्यवेद)
nodes.description: The science of architecture, engineering, and construction. Associated with the Atharvaveda. Includes principles of town planning, building temples, and vastu-śāstra.

nodes.name:
Dharma Shastra
(धर्मशास्त्र)
nodes.description: A category of Smṛti texts that prescribe dharma (law, ethics, conduct) based on the Vedas. Includes rules for individuals, society, and legal procedures.

nodes.name: Dharma Sūtras
nodes.description: Early prose texts attached to Vedic schools outlining rules on dharma, rituals, and conduct.

nodes.name: Āpastamba Dharma Sūtra
nodes.description: One of the earliest Dharma Sūtras, associated with the Taittirīya branch of the Yajurveda. Covers duties, penances, and rituals.

nodes.name: Baudhāyana Dharma Sūtra
nodes.description: Associated with the Kṛṣṇa Yajurveda; discusses rituals, caste duties, and penances.

nodes.name: Gautama Dharma Sūtra
nodes.description: Possibly the oldest Dharma Sūtra; linked with the Sāmaveda; emphasizes social and legal duties.

nodes.name: Vasiṣṭha Dharma Sūtra
nodes.description: Covers purification, ethics, and dharma, possibly from an independent or lost Vedic tradition.

nodes.name: Dharma Smṛtis
nodes.description: Verse-form law codes elaborating on Dharma Sūtras; more developed, poetic, and systematic.

nodes.name: Manu Smṛti
nodes.description: The most well-known Dharmaśāstra, divided into 12 chapters covering ethics, law, and social order.

nodes.name: Yājñavalkya Smṛti
nodes.description: A more concise and juridically oriented Dharmaśāstra, widely used in medieval Hindu law.

nodes.name: Nārada Smṛti
nodes.description: Specializes in legal procedure, judgeship, and court matters; foundational for Hindu law.

nodes.name: Parāśara Smṛti
nodes.description: Applies dharma to the Kali Yuga; seen as more lenient and family-oriented.

nodes.name: Bṛhaspati Smṛti
nodes.description: Focuses on law and economics; mostly survives in quotations and secondary references.

nodes.name: Kātyāyana Smṛti
nodes.description: Deals with judicial procedure and property law.

nodes.name:
Darshan Shastra
(दर्शनशास्त्र)
nodes.description: The word Darśana comes from the root √dṛś (to see). It means a particular way or perspective of seeing the ultimate truth (tattva). All texts belonging to 6 Darshanas (Philosophy) : Nyāya, Vaiśeṣika, Sāṅkhya, Yoga, Mīmāṁsā, Vedānta accepts authority of Vedas. These Darshan/philosophies are based on various Darshan Sutras witten by Rishis.

nodes.name:
Nyāya
(न्यायशास्त्र)
nodes.description: A system of logic and epistemology founded by Gautama. Nyāya focuses on valid means of knowledge (pramāṇas), critical reasoning, and debate as tools to attain liberation through true knowledge.

nodes.name:
Vaiśeṣika
(वैशेषिकशास्त्र)
nodes.description: Founded by Kaṇāda, Vaiśeṣika presents a metaphysical system based on atomic theory and categorization of reality (padārthas). It explains the physical world as composed of eternal atoms and real substances, qualities, and actions.

nodes.name:
Sāṅkhya
(सांख्यशास्त्र)
nodes.description: A dualistic system founded by sage Kapila, Sāṅkhya distinguishes between conscious self (puruṣa) and unconscious matter (prakṛti). Liberation is achieved by discriminative knowledge that separates the two.

nodes.name:
Yoga
(योगशास्त्र)
nodes.description: Codified by Patañjali in the Yoga Sūtras, Yoga builds on Sāṅkhya by integrating meditative practice and theism. Its eightfold path (aṣṭāṅga yoga) leads to mental discipline and spiritual liberation (kaivalya).

nodes.name:
Mīmāṁsā
(पूर्वमीमांसाशास्त्र)
nodes.description: Also called Pūrva-Mīmāṁsā, this system, founded by Jaimini, emphasizes the ritualistic portion of the Vedas (karma-kāṇḍa). It affirms the authority of the Vedas and focuses on dharma through proper performance of Vedic duties.

nodes.name:
Vedānta
(वेदान्तशास्त्र)
nodes.description: Also known as Uttara-Mīmāṁsā, Vedānta interprets the philosophical portion of the Vedas (Upaniṣads). Based on the Brahma Sūtras, it explores the nature of Brahman, the soul, and liberation. Includes Advaita, Viśiṣṭādvaita, Dvaita, and other schools.

nodes.name: Advaita
nodes.description: Only Brahman exists ultimately (non-dual). The world and individual identities are illusory appearances (māyā)

nodes.name: Dvaita
nodes.description: Brahman (Viṣṇu) is eternally distinct from souls and matter.

nodes.name: Vishishtadvaita
nodes.description: Brahman is qualified by attributes — the sentient (jīvas) and insentient (matter) are real, and form His body.

nodes.name: Suddhadvaita
nodes.description: Everything is Brahman. No māyā, no illusion. The world is a real manifestation of God

nodes.name: Dvaitādvaita
nodes.description: There is simultaneous difference and non-difference between Brahman, jīva, and jagat.

details.classification: Puranas are classified as Sattva (Vaishnava), Rajas (Brahma), and Tamas (Shaiva) Puranas.
details.note: Each Purana contains five topics: creation, destruction, genealogy, reigns of Manus, and history of dynasties.

nodes.name: Vishnu Purana
nodes.description: Stories and philosophy of Lord Vishnu.

nodes.name: Matsya Purana
nodes.description: Stories of Matsya avatar and Shiva.

nodes.name: Shiva Purana
nodes.description: Glory and stories of Lord Shiva.

details.examples: Examples: Sanatkumara, Narasimha, Brihannaradiya, Sivarahasya, Durvasa, Kapila, Vamana, Kalika, Samba, etc.

nodes.name: Harivamsa
nodes.description: Harivamsa is the part of Mahabharata which is about the life of Lord Krishna.
